results.title: Glasses
results.creator_credit: Marcy Page, ONF | NFB and Brian Duchscherer
results.brief_description: Young Milo is a sensitive boy who like most other children just wants to be accepted at school. Above all, he yearns for the freedom and independence enjoyed by his comic book hero, Captain Cosmo, and resents his mother’s constant care and attention especially the plain, generic lunchbox she gives him instead of a Captain Cosmo one that all his other classmates own. What really holds Milo back is his poor eyesight: the world is fuzzy and this makes things difficult. He is rejected by the soccer team because he cannot score properly and ridiculed in class because he constantly misreads the numbers on the cards which his teacher puts before him. However, a trip to the optometrist and a pair of glasses improves things. But not totally. Though Milo can now read the numbers correctly in class, he still encounters trouble at soccer and bullying from his classmates. When things are at rock bottom however, Milo learns what is important and has his first experience of accepting life for what it is. Brian Duchscherer’s puppet animation is a joy to watch and brings to vivid life recognisable characters and important themes.

results.title: Glass houses
results.brief_description: Dramatizes the responsibility of many social institutions for juvenile delinquency and for measures to reduce it. When a teenage boy is brought to trial for theft, the prosecutor also indicts the agencies of society which helped to shape his character. The church, the school, municipal government and the father are questioned about their efforts to prevent juvenile delinquency. All are found guilty and reminded of their responsibility for the welfare of youth.

results.title: Glass curtain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doris Chase Concepts”.
A dance film in which a woman tries to cope with the dimming mind of her mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. Dancer Jennie Ventriss. Music by Katherine Hoover.

results.title: Glass
results.creator_credit: Pilkington Brothers, Cecil Musk and Frank Worth
results.brief_description: An ancient Roman comes to life and tours the Pilkington glassworks. He discovers modern methods of manufacture and the wide range of uses for glass products; in aviation, at home, in industry, science and building. Each item’s use and manufacture is demonstrates (with a streak of comedy to lighten the approach) including the grinding and polishing of lenses, the medieval technique of making glass by hand and mechanical glass blowing.

results.title: Glass
results.brief_description: Portrays without commentary the deft craftsmanship of glass blowers, highlighting the artistry and individuality of their work. Contrasts this with machines which produce bottles and glass jars automatically.

results.title: Glasgow 1980
results.creator_credit: Ogam Films, Films of Scotland, City of Glascow and Oscar Marzaroli
results.brief_description: The urban renewal of Glasgow. The biggest urban renewal in Europe. A 20 year program begun in 1960 involving 550 miles or one twelth of the City area. Shows what has been achieved and what will be achieved by 1980. Editing by Bill Forsyth. Narrated by Michael Harrigan.

results.title: Glaciers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Shows the formation of many different types glaciers and describes the effect of glacial action as seen in the lakes of the Rockies, soil in the American Corn Belt, glacial drift in new England, and the Matterhorn peak in the Swiss Alps.

results.title: Glacier on the move
results.brief_description: Shows a glacier in action, illustrating the rhythm of glacial movement in summer and winter, and the effects of gravity, temperature and pressure on glacial movement.
